newsitem.title: INDIA: Tax cuts, sops likely in India budget - papers.
newsitem.headline: Tax cuts, sops likely in India budget - papers.

text.p: Indian newspapers have forecast several measures likely to be announced in the country's 1997/98 (April-March) federal budget, due to be unveiled by Finance Minister P. Chidambaram on Friday.
The following are some highlights:
ON TAXES

** The Business Standard says Finance Minister P. Chidambaram is expected to unveil a big-bang budget which could include direct tax changes like the withdrawal of double taxation of dividends, introduction of an expenditure-based assessment in the case of professionals like doctors and engineers and a possible tax on expenditure.
A 7.5 percent corporate surcharge is likely to be withdrawn, the newspaper says.

It adds that policy changes relating to indirect taxes could include a reduction in average level of tariff to around 30 percent from the current 40. The peak tariff rate is likely to remain unchanged.

** The Financial Express says luxury tax levies are likely in the federal budget including a $5,000 fee on non-resident Indians, levies on telephone ownership, large electricity consumers, domestic air travel, cars and property ownership.
ON THE FISCAL DEFICIT
** Business Standard sees renewed effort to curb burgeoning fiscal deficit and further fillip to tax reforms in forthcoming budget.
An ambitious divestment target is expected to make up for enhanced social spending. Chidambaram is likely to propose a fiscal deficit target of 4.5 percent of GDP for 1997/98.
ON CAPITAL MARKETS
** State Bank of India Chairman P.G. Kakodkar says in the Observer newspaper that Chidambaram's first target should be improving capital market conditions.
This includes eliminating double taxation on dividends, restructuring MAT and exempting some shares relating to infrastructure from capital gains tax.

** Economic Times says recent Economic Survey statement that "tax deductions and exemptions cannot be a substitute for reforms of policy and procedures," is significant in view of the persistent demands from capital markets for tax reliefs to revive markets.
INFRASTRUCTURE
** The Economic Times says a fresh round of policy statements on infrastructure is likely.

Announcements could include allowing insurance companies, pension and provident funds to invest a sizeable percent of their corpus either in infrastructure funds or directly in projects and an exemption or reduction of tariffs on imports of technology required for infrastructure projects.
EXPORTS
** The Economic Times says commerce ministry has put forward list seeking tax concessions to help exports.
The government could identify thrust export industries like leather, gems and jewellery, and textiles where fiscal incentives could be increased. Could dilute MAT for exporters.
